page.title: 14Ecology(4) in Leverton
page.content: The whole of our area,including the outmarsh,is used for shooting,both wildfowling and game,and many birds are shot,deliberately or by mistake, which should not be shot.Pheasants and partridges are reared for shooting and the only vermin now disposed of are foxes and rats.Pesticides,however,are responsible for other "accidental" disappearances.Butterflies are now not as common as they once were because their food supply is no longer allowed to grow as it used to do.Only one small patch of phragmites reed still grows and has a small breeding population of sedge warblers.Frogs and toads are non-existent but newts can still be found in one or two places. Progress in farming methods have their casualties and not all progress has been for the better,particularly for the wildlife.
